docs.lead_paragraph: Here is a selective listing by critics of The New York Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show. Museums ''THE CHANGING FACE OF LIBERTY: FEMALE ALLEGORIES OF AMERICA,'' New-York Historical Society, 2 West 77th Street, (212) 873-3400 (through Sept. 3). Uncle Sam, the allegorical male personification of the United States, has always had a female counterpart, the damsel dressed in flowing robes who came to symbolize Liberty. As a sequel to its ''Uncle Sam'' show, the historical society mounted this very lively display of his iconic sister in her many guises, from ''L'Amerique,'' an Indian princess with feathers in her hair who represented the New World in early maps, to the matronly Lady Liberty portrayed in the Bartholdi statue in New York Harbor. The fascinating story of Liberty's evolution is told in posters, cartoons, illustrations and photographs. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 11 a.m. to 5 p.m. Admission: $5; $3 for students over 12 and the elderly (Grace Glueck).

docs.lead_paragraph: Using ovulation-inducing drugs to treat infertility carries a significant risk of producing unwanted multiple births, even when doctors carefully follow the standard guidelines, a new study has confirmed. The study researchers, whose findings are in today's issue of the New England Journal of Medicine, suggested that doctors instead rely on in vitro fertilization, in which eggs and sperm meet in a laboratory dish, and implanting only two of the resulting embryos at a time.

headline.main: Treatment Tied To Increased Multiple Births

docs.abstract: New study by researchers at Center for Human Reproduction in Chicago confirms that using ovulation-inducing drugs to treat infertility carries significant risk of producing unwanted multiple births, even when doctors carefully follow standard guidelines (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: SO, an economist, a magician and a man with attention deficit disorder are sitting in a hotel room. That's not the setup for a joke, it's simply one of the many encounters that took place here in June at a weekend meeting of about 70 people with diverse professions, hobbies and afflictions who attended a two-day conference to commune, confess and complain about the one thing they had in common: their roles as the remote work force of the Web site About.com.

headline.main: A Bevy of Experts With Soapboxes, and Sites to Fill

docs.abstract: International Business Machines Corp is embarked on five-year, $100 million program to build the world's most powerful supercomputer, named Blue Gene, whose mission will be to simulate the folding of proteins, an enourmous task that could yield new understanding of Alzheimer's or mad cow disease and aid in drug design; machine will have a 'processor in memory,' or PIM, design, meaning that memory will be on the same chip as the processor; IBM says computer will be 'self-healing,' capable or running when processors fail; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A new report suggests that while women taking birth control pills -- even the newer, low-dose forms -- are at higher risk of stroke, that risk is outweighed by the contraceptive benefits of the pills. And in any event, the report in today's issue of the Journal of the American Medical Association said, strokes are so rare in women of reproductive age that the increase is of little significance. The low-dose forms, taken by most of the more than 10 million American women using oral contraceptives, contain less estrogen and are thought to be safer. Still, women taking them were nearly twice as likely as non-users to suffer a stroke, while women using higher-dose pills faced nearly a threefold risk.

headline.main: Report Weighs Benefits and Risks of Pill

docs.abstract: New report suggests that while women taking birth control pills in even newer, low-dose forms are at higher risk of stroke, the risk is outweighed by contraceptive benefits of medication (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: NEW YORK BAY SHORE: FATAL FIREWORKS A 34-year-old Long Island man was decapitated last night when he bent over some lit fireworks to check on them and they exploded, the police said. The accident occurred at 9:30 p.m. in an empty lot along a Sunrise Highway service road. No other information was available. (AP) QUEENS: REWARD DOUBLED A resort in Kingston, Jamaica, has doubled the reward for information about a New York travel writer who disappeared while staying at one of its camps. On Monday, Sandals Resorts raised the payment to $50,000 for clues about the writer, Claudia Kirschhoch, 29, who works at Frommer's Travel Guides. Ms. Kirschhoch, who had been staying at a Sandals resort in western Negril, was reported missing on June 2. An Astoria resident, she arrived in Jamaica on May 24 as part of a Sandals-sponsored tour for travel writers, and was last seen on May 27. (AP) MANHATTAN: ROBBERY ARREST Michael Contessa's mistake, the police said, was one of timing: his robbery of a crowded nightclub was undone by a more elaborate endeavor. Early yesterday, Mr. Contessa and two other men robbed Exit, a club on West 56th Street, the police said, only to be captured by officers preparing the block for the Fourth of July celebration. The officers were keeping cars from parking on streets that adjoin the Hudson River when they got a call about the robbery. The three men were caught nearby, the police said. Kevin Flynn (NYT)

docs.lead_paragraph: I have a daughter and three sons. If there is better duty than being the dad, I have never found it. But on one subject -- the nature of sex and its possible outcomes -- the counsel I'm required to give my sons, if given to my daughter, sounds unfashionably bombastic, politically suspect if not ''incorrect,'' vaguely patriarchal. Oughtn't parenting be gender-neutral? I'm in favor of life, in favor of choice. Life is not easy. Neither is choice.
docs.abstract: Thomas Lynch Op-Ed article argues that just as a woman has a legal right to abort an unwanted baby, a man should have right to declare his interest in a fetus null and void and be relieved of financial responsibility for any child that is born; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Babies born weighing less than five and a half pounds are almost four times more likely not to graduate from high school by age 19 than their normal-birthweight siblings, according to a study in the June issue of the American Sociological Review. The findings of the study, apparently the first to follow low-birthweight children to age 19, are far more dramatic than the academic problems documented in previous studies tracking children for fewer years. And the extent of the educational gap came as a troubling surprise to some experts in the field.

headline.main: Learning Problems of Low-Weight Infants Are Broader Than Once Thought, Study Finds

docs.abstract: Study by American Sociological Review finds babies born weighing less than five and a half pounds are almost four times more likely not to graduate from high school by age 19 than their normal-birthweight siblings; in families studied, 57.5 percent of normal-birthweight siblings graduated from high school by time they were 19, compared with 15.2 percent of low birth-weight siblings; sociologists say timely high school graduation is important indicator because those who do not graduate on time are more likely to receive equivalency diploma and less likely to go on to four-year college than those who complete high school on time (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: After generations on family bookshelves, the tale in Frances Hodgson Burnett's children's book ''The Secret Garden'' is widely familiar: two children, unloved and neglected, find new life in the discovery of an unloved and neglected garden. Perhaps as inspirational, but far less familiar, is the tale behind the Connie Gretz Secret Garden, a children's center in the Snug Harbor Cultural Center on Staten Island.

headline.main: Unsecret Garden Is Tribute to Love

docs.abstract: Connie Gretz Secret Garden, in Snug Harbor Cultural Center on Staten Island, was built by Randy Gretz in memory of wife who died in 1996 from cancer; garden includes castle, puppet theater and hedge maze; photo (M)
